description: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.
title: Practice: Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles

uid: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue-alpha
title: Practice: Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue
description: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).

title: Lose vs. Loose
description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing.
We use the word off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.

Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.
title: Use Commas in Addresses
Practice: A, An, The
description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).

title: Practice: Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases
description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).

title: But
description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I don’t like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti, but I don’t like hamburgers.
But connects two contrasting sentences into one larger one. In the example, but is used to show that the subject (I) likes spaghetti, but not hamburgers.

title: Singular Possessive
description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

title: Either ... Or
description: Exactly Two Options: You can have either soup or salad. Two Options, Maybe More: You can have soup or salad. Whenever either is placed before or, we are presented with exactly two options (soup or salad). If the two options share a verb, either is written after the verb (have either). If the two options have different verbs, either is written before the first verb (either have).

title: The Passive Voice
description: Active: I ate the chocolate bar on the table. Passive: The chocolate bar on the table was eaten. Verbs in the passive voice are made the same way past participles are made (eaten). They follow helping verbs like “was” and “were.”

Correct: If I were you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. Incorrect: If I was you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. When we wish for something, or wonder if something could happen, we use ""were"" instead of ""was"".
title: Verb Mood Shift

description: With Ellipsis: ""I forgot what I went shopping for..."" Without Ellipsis: ""I forgot what I went shopping for."" Ellipses are used in informal writing. Like commas, they are used to show a pause. However, the ellipsis is often used when someone is speaking, and can also be used to show that the person hasn't finished what he or she might have said.
title: Ellipsis

description:
Adjective: The park we visited was really beautiful. Adverb: You performed beautifully yesterday.
Adjectives (beautiful) are used to describe nouns (park).
title: Adjectives

description:
Adjective: Careful, that knife is sharp. Adverb: I sharply turned the car around.
If an adjective ends in a consonant (sharp), then we usually add ""ly"" onto the end of the adjective to make it an adverb (sharply).
title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Consonant Ending

description:
Adjective: I was really happy this morning. Adverb: I will happily go out tonight.
Adjectives ending in ""y"" (happy), become adverbs by changing the ""y"" to an ""i"", and then adding ""ly""(happily).
title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""y""
Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""le""
description:
Adjective: I think this task is pretty simple. Adverb: You simply put the ball in the net.
Adjectives ending in ""le"" (simple), become adverbs by changing the ""le"" to ""ly""(simply).

title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""e""
description:
Adjective: You are brave enough to face your fears. Adverb: Rita bravely faced her fears.
Adjectives ending in ""e"" (brave), become adverbs by simply adding ""ly"" to the end of the word (bravely).

title: Can't
description:
Separate: I can not see in the dark. Contraction: I can't see in the dark.
To make ""can"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write can't.

Separate: I will not sign anything until I've read the contract. Contraction: I won't sign anything until I've read the contract.
To make ""will"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write won't.
title: Won't

description: Lose: I lose my keys; I lose my balance. Loose: The screws were loose; It broke loose. Lose refers to a loss. Loose means to let go or the opposite of tight.
title: Lose vs. Loose

description:
Examples: John, Sarah, London, Japan, and Yankees
Proper nouns are names for people, places, and things, such as John, or Japan. All proper nouns are capitalized.
title: Proper Nouns
Common Nouns
description:
Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.

Correct: My brother wrote me an email, but I never received it. Incorrect: My brother writed me an email, but I never received it.
The past tense of ""write"" is wrote.
title: Wrote

description:
Correct: I finally found my phone in my backpack. Incorrect: I finally finded my phone in my backpack.
The past tense of ""find"" is found.
title: Found

description:
Adjective: My car is really slow. Adverb: I drive slowly when it is raining.
Adverbs are used to describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They usually describe how an action is being done (drive slowly).
title: Adverbs

description:
Separate: I do not go to school on Saturday. Contraction: I don't go to school on Saturday.
To make ""do"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write don't.
title: Don't

description:
Separate: I have not contacted Mrs. Robinson. Contraction: I haven't contacted Mrs. Robinson.
To make ""have"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write haven't.
title: Haven't

description:
Separate: I have been to Mexico before. Contraction: I've been to Mexico before.
To make a contraction with ""I"" and ""have"", we write I've.
title: I've
That's
description:
Separate: That is a good idea. Contraction: That's a good idea.
To make a contraction with ""that"" and ""is"", we write that's.

Separate: You are responsible for logging your work. Contraction: You're responsible for logging your work.
We use you're to say that you are doing something.
title: You're
Lose vs. Loose
description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.
Correct: We have made many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. Incorrect: We have maked many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. The past participle for ""make"" is made.
title: Made
Lost
description: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.

title: Gone
description: Correct: Velma has gone to visit her brother in the hospital. Incorrect: Velma has goed to visit her brother in the hospital. The past participle of ""go"" is gone.

title: Verb Tense
description: Correct: I laughed, I cried, and I shouted during the performance. Incorrect: I laughed, I was crying, and I shout during the performance. Sentences flow easily when all the actions in a list have the same ending. This means that each and every action in a list stays in the past, present, or future tense.

Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.
title: Singular And Plural Nouns
Collective Nouns
description:
Correct: There is a huge crowd of people at the front gate. Incorrect: There is a huge crowds of people at the front gate.
Collective nouns are words like group, bunch, gallon, bouquet, etc. They usually are singular and describe a group of things (group of people).
If there are multiple groups of things, you pluralize the collective noun (two armies, two herds, etc). For example, if you are trying to say that there are two groups of soldiers, you say there are two armies, not two army.

Correct: Some people say cats have nine lives. Incorrect: Some people say cats have nine lifes.
Nouns that end in ""fe"" (life) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""fe"" (life) to ""ves"" (lives).
title: Ends with ""fe""

description:
Reflexive: I hit myself with a ball playing soccer yesterday. Non-Reflexive: I was hit with a ball while playing soccer yesterday.
If a subject (I) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (myself). In the second example, the subject (I) does not do something to itself, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
title: Myself
Yourself
description:
Reflexive: Why don't you lift yourself out of the hole? Non-Reflexive: Why don't you lift Alex out of the hole?
If a subject (you) does something to its itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourself). Sentences where the subject (you) does not do something to itself (Alex) do not use a reflexive pronoun.

Correct: I did too much work today. Incorrect: I doed too much work today.
The past tense of ""do"" is did.
title: Did

description:
Correct: I once ate three hot dogs at the same time. Incorrect: I once eated three hot dogs at the same time.
The past tense of ""eat"" is ate.
title: Ate
Whose
description:
Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).

title: Made
description:
Correct: I made a vase out of clay. Incorrect: I maked a vase out of clay.
The past tense of ""make"" is made.

title: So
description:
Not Connected: I don't like hamburgers. I will have spaghetti. Connected: I don't like hamburgers, so I will have spaghetti.
So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.

title: Because
description:
Not Connected: I like this spaghetti. There is a lot of cheese in it. Connected: I like this spaghetti because there is a lot of cheese in it.
Because connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, because is used to show that the amount of cheese is the reason the spaghetti is liked.

title: Practice: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, & Geographic Names

description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.
title: Using Periods
And
description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.

Separate: It is really great you decided to come. Contraction: It's really great you decided to come.
To make a contraction with ""it"" and ""is"", we write it's.
title: It's

description: Correct: Our librarian always reminds us, ""Speak softly in the library."" Incorrect: Our librarian always reminds us, "" Speak softly in the library."" Whenever we use quotation marks, they always go right next to a word or punctuation (""Speak softly in the library.""). We never put in extra spaces between quotation marks and the words next to them.
title: Using Quotation Marks
Past Tense
description:
Past: I walked to school. Present: I walk to school.
When we want to talk about things that happened earlier, we usually add ""ed"" to the end of regular verbs to make them past tense.

Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).
title: Future Tense

description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.
title: Who
Whom
description:
Correct: My father, whom I respect, is a self-made man. Incorrect: My father, who I respect, is a self-made man.
We use whom to give more details about someone (My father) who receives an action (I respect) instead of doing an action. The example above says that someone (I) respects her father, which means that ""father"" receives the action, ""respect"".

title: Where
description:
Correct: Let's go to the living room, where we will serve drinks. Incorrect: Let's go to the living room, when we will serve drinks.
Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).

Correct: My favorite time of year is autumn, when all the leaves change color. Incorrect: My favorite time of year is autumn, where all the leaves change color.
When is used to to talk about something happening (leaves change color) in on, or at a certain time (autumn).
title: When

description:
Correct: Please tell me why you missed the meeting. Incorrect: Please tell me where you missed the meeting.
Why is used to talk about something happening (missed the meeting) for a certain reason.
title: Why
Present Progressive
description:
Simple Present: Jesse thinks about seagulls. Present Progressive: Jesse is thinking about seagulls right now.
Present progressive tense describes an ongoing action that is happening right now (Jesse is thinking right now). This tense is made by putting words like “am,” “is”, and “are” before the verb, and adding “ing” to the end of the verb (is thinking).

Simple Past: James cleaned the mess he made when his mom walked in the room. Past Progressive: James was cleaning the mess he made when his mom walked in the room.
Past progressive tense describes something which was happening (was cleaning) when something else occurred (mom walked in). This tense is made by putting words like “was” or “were” before the verb and adding “ing” at the end of the verb (was cleaning).
title: Past Progressive
Geographic Names
description:
Correct: I am moving to Los Angeles next month. Incorrect: I am moving to los angeles next month.
We capitalize the names of all geographic places (cities, countries, towns, mountains, etc).

title: Which
description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.

Permission: May we go to the park tomorrow? I really want to go! Ability: Can we go to the park tomorrow? Do we have enough time?
We use may to ask or give permission. We use can to say we have the ability to do something.
title: Can vs. May
Should vs. Must
description:
Advice: You should go to the doctor. Emergency: You must go to the doctor.
We use the word must when we want to emphasize that something needs to be done. We use should when we want to suggest or give advice.

title: Prepositional Phrases: Adjective
description:
Prepositional Adjective: The man behind the bench is waiting for the bus.
An adjective prepositional phrase describes what something looks like. Adjective prepositional phrases (behind the bench) are placed after a noun (man).

title: Prepositional Phrases: Adverb
description:
Prepositional Adverb: The man reached under the desk.
An adverbial prepositional phrase describes how something is being done.
Adverb prepositional phrases (under the desk) are placed after a verb (reached).

It's: It's time to go. Its: The dog wags its tail.
It's is the same as ""it is"".
Its is possessive, meaning the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).
title: Its vs. It's
Of vs. Off
description:
Of: a button of a coat, north of Chicago, member of a team. Off: turn off the lights, my shoes are off, break off some bread.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing.
We use the word off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.

title: Than vs. Then
description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""

title: There, They're, & Their
description:
There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their frisbee at the park.
There is used for locations.
They're is the same as ""they are"".
Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).

Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.
title: First Word of a Sentence

description:
Correct: Do you have a class with Mr. Thompson? Incorrect: Do you have a class with mr. thompson?
We always capitalize the first letter of proper nouns (Mr. Thompson), which are people, places, and things, with names. We also capitalize any titles that might come before the proper noun, such as Mr., Ms., Dr., President, Professor, ect. Don't forget, ""I"" is a proper noun and is always capitalized.
title: Proper Nouns
Quotations
description:
Correct: We heard a booming voice shout, ""Who are you?"" Incorrect: We heard a booming voice shout, ""who are you?""
When we use quotations in a sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (Who) of the quote as though it was starting a new sentence.

Correct: I live on 15 Deepwood Rd in Hartford CT. Incorrect: I live on 15 deepwood rd in hartford ct.
The names of roads, towns, and states in addresses are all proper nouns, so they are capitalized. Don't forget to capitalize all the proper nouns in your address whenever you write it down.
title: Addresses

description:
Correct: Will you please call her when you finish the poster? Incorrect: Will you please call she when you finish the poster? Also Incorrect: Will you please call hers when you finish the poster?
Object pronouns (her) are words like ""me"", ""you"", ""him"", ""her"", ""it"", ""us"", and ""them"". Object pronouns go after the verb (call).
title: Object Pronouns

description:
Correct: Our project is more difficult than theirs. Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than they. Also Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than them.
Possessive pronouns (theirs) are words like ""mine"", ""yours"", ""his"", ""hers"", ""its"", ""ours"", and ""theirs"". They refer to something the subject owns (project).
title: Possessive Pronouns
Product Names
description:
Correct: My favorite baseball team is the Yankees. Incorrect: My favorite baseball team is the yankees.
We capitalize all product names. Product names include companies (Microsoft), sports teams (Yankees), and brand names (Coca-Cola).

title: To, Too, & Two
description:
To: I sent an email to you. Too: Brett sent you an email too. Two: Pat sent you not one, but two emails.
To is used mostly to show where something is moving Too can either mean ""also"" or ""excessive"". Two is the number after ""one"".

Is: John is behind the curtain. Are: The men are next to the bar. Am: I am under a bridge.
A nominal prepositional phrase is used to say where something is. Nominal prepositional phrases (behind the curtain, next to the bar, under a bridge) are placed after the verb to be (is, are, am).
title: Prepositional Phrases: Noun

description:
Your: I need to borrow your umbrella. You're: I hope that you're going to lend me one.
We use your when something belongs to ""you."" You're means ""you are.""
title: Your vs. You're

description:
Correct: Victor, Lucas, and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor,Lucas,and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor ,Lucas ,and Don play basketball.
We put a space after a comma. We do not put a space before a comma.
title: Using Commas
Been
description: Correct: I have been in a band before. Incorrect: I have beed in a band before. The past participle for ""be"" is been.

At: I will meet my friend at 2:30. In: I will meet my friend in the fall. On: I will meet my friend on Monday. We use at for specific times, like 1:30 PM or 7:00 AM. We use in for months, seasons, and times of day, like October, winter, or morning. We use on for days of the week and certain dates, like Monday or October 30th.
title: Prepositions (Time): At, In, On.
Practice: Pronoun Shift
uid: Recognizing Innapropriate Shifts in Pronoun Number or Gender-alpha

description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. [My father owns the stamp collection] Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. [The sails belong to the ship] Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word. Whatever comes after the possessive noun belongs to it. For example, my father's stamp collection and the ship's sail are possessive nouns.
title: Possessive Nouns
Capitalize Dates
description: Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994. Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).

classification: Irregular Verbs in the Past Tense
description: Incorrect: I finally finded my phone in my backpack. Correct: I finally found my phone in my backpack. The past tense of ""find"" is found.
title: Irregular Verbs in the Past Tense: Find

description:
Vague: Mary orchestrated tonight's show and has a nice singing voice. It is just one of her many talents. Specific: Mary orchestrated tonight's show and has a nice singing voice. Her singing voice is just one of her many talents.
In the first example, it is not clear whether it refers to Mary's signing voice or to Mary's orchestration of the concert.
In the second sentence, it is replaced with her singing voice. It is now clear that Mary's talent is her singing voice.
title: Vague Pronouns: One Subject
Vague Pronouns: More Than One Subject
description:
Vague: Mary orchestrated tonight's show, while Tia was in charge of all the design work. She works really hard. Specific: Mary orchestrated tonight's show, while Tia was in charge of all the design work. Tia works really hard.
In the first example, it is not clear whether she refers to Mary or to Tia.
In the second sentence Tia replaces she, making it clear who works really hard.

title: Pronoun Shift: Singular
description:
Correct: A doctor has an important job because she saves lives. Correct: A doctor has an important job because he saves lives. Incorrect: A doctor has an important job because they save lives.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is singular (doctor), then any pronouns referring to it will will usually be singular as well (he, she).

Correct: If they stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them. Incorrect: If you stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is plural (they), then any pronouns referring to it will usually be plural as well (them).
title: Pronoun Shift: Plural
Commas Around Clauses
description:
Correct: My sister, who just received her law degree, is moving to New York. Incorrect: My sister who just received her law degree is moving to New York.
We put commas before and after nonrestrictive clauses (,who just received her law degree,). Nonrestrictive clauses provide additional information about a subject. We use these commas to show that this information is less important.

title: It's vs. Its
description: It's: It's a nice day. Its: The dog wags its tail. It's is the same as ""it is"". Its means the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).

title: Articles: A, An
description: A: I climbed a tree. An: I climbed an oak tree. Articles (a, an) are used before nouns (tree, oak tree). We use ""a"" before nouns that start with a consonant sound (everything but a, e, i, o, u). We use ""an"" before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).

There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their Frisbee at the park. There is used for locations. They're is the same as ""they are"". Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).
title: There, They're, Their

description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).
title: Holidays

description:
Not Connected: Would you like spaghetti? Would you like a hamburger? Connected: Would you like spaghetti, or would you like a hamburger?
Or connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, or is used to show a choice between spaghetti or a hamburger.
title: Or
Man vs. Men
description:
Correct: Are you mice, or are you men? Incorrect: Are you mice, or are you mans?
The word ""man"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (man) to an ""e"" (men).

Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).
title: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue

description:
Correct: They hiked 1.7 miles. Incorrect: They hiked 1. 7 miles.
We do not put a space before or after a period when we are writing numbers.
title: Using Periods with Numbers
Using Commas with Numbers
description:
Correct: 1,500,000 Incorrect: 1, 500, 000
We do not put a space before or after a comma when we are writing numbers.

title: Adjectives Ending in ""y""
description: Correct: Papayas are considered to be healthier than bananas. Incorrect: Papayas are considered to be healthyer than bananas. To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) comparative, we change the ""y"" to an ""ier"" to the end of the word (**healthier**).

title: Comparative Adjectives
description: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).

title: Superlative Adjectives
description: Correct: James is the tallest guy in school. Incorrect: James is the most tall guy in school. Superlative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is the ""most"" or ""least"". Regular superlative adjectives are formed by adding ""est"" to the end of a word (**tallest**).

Correct: Are papayas the healthiest fruit of all? Incorrect: Are papayas the healthyest fruitof all? To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) superlative, we change the ""y"" to an ""iest"" to the end of the word (**healthiest**).
title: Adjectives ending in ""y"" (Superlative)
Better & Best
description: Correct: Who here is the best at playing chess? Incorrect: Who here is the goodest at playing chess? The comparative adjective for ""good"" is better. The superlative adjective for ""good"" is best.

Correct: It is worse to have never tried than to fail. Incorrect: It is badder to have never tried than to fail. The comparative adjective for ""bad"" is worse. The superlative adjective for ""bad"" is worst.
title: Worse & Worst

description: Niether … nor: My friend is neither snowboarding nor skiing today. Either … or: My friend is either snowboarding or skiing today. Neither and nor are used the same way as the words ""either"" and ""or"". However, neither and nor are used for negative sentences.
title: Neither ... Nor
Both ... And
description: With Both: Both Tom and Michelle like swimming. Without Both: Tom likes swimming. Michelle also likes swimming. Both can be used with and to describe two things at the same time (Both Tom and Michelle). We place both before the first thing, then use and for the second thing.

title: Plural Possessive
description: Many Boys: Do not touch the boys' gear. One Boy: Do not touch the boy's gear. When multiple people or things own something we place an apostrophe after the ""s"" (boys'). When just one person or thing owns something we put the apostrophe before the ""s"".

title: Hid
description:
Correct: Janice hid a note in my backpack. Incorrect: Janice hided a note in my backpack.
The past tense of ""hide"" is hid.

title: Knew
description:
Correct: In middle school, Lisa knew more about animals than anyone else. Incorrect: In middle school, Lisa knowed more about animals than anyone else.
The past tense of ""know"" is knew.

Correct: That lady spoke to me in a nasty tone. Incorrect: That lady speaked to me in a nasty tone.
The past tense of ""speak"" is spoke.
title: Spoke

description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.
title: This & That

description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).
title: The
Commas in a List
description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.

title: Colons
description: Correct: The box was filled with stuff: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. Incorrect: The box has: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. We use colons (filled with stuff:) to begin a list. Colons can only be used after complete sentences. Colons are never placed after main verb of the sentence they are added too. After the colon begins the list, we place commas after each item in the list.

Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to agree, disagree, or confirm what someone just said. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we).
title: Tag Questions

description: Correct: Yes, my husband is a lawyer. Incorrect: Yes my husband is a lawyer. Correct: No, I don't want to go. Incorrect: No I don't want to go. When we begin a sentence with yes or no, we always put a comma afterwards.
title: Yes & No

description: Correct: Can we go, Paul? Incorrect: Can we go Paul? Correct: Sarah, you should go to practice. Incorrect: Sarah you should go to practice. If we address somebody at the end of a sentence, we place a comma before their name. If we address somebody at the beginning of a sentence we place a comma after their name.
title: Addressing People
Writing Lists
description:
Incorrect: I'll have milk and toast and a muffin. Correct: I'll have milk, toast, and a muffin.
When we write lists of three or more, we put a comma after each item in the list. We also put the word ""and"" before the last item of the list.

title: Capitalization: Dates
description:
Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).

title: In (Time)
description:
Correct: I will meet my cousin in the fall. Incorrect: I will meet my cousin at the fall.
We use in for months, seasons, and times of day, like October, winter or morning.

title: In (Place)
description:
Correct: I had a great time in London. Incorrect: I had a great time at London.
We use in when we are inside or within a place, like in France, or in a car.

Correct: I will meet with my counselor on Monday. Incorrect: I will meet with my counselor in Monday.
We use on for days of the week and certain dates, like Monday or October 30th.
title: On (Time)
On (Place)
description:
Correct: My grandparents keep a picture of me on their mantle. Incorrect: My grandparents keep a picture of me at their mantle.
We use on for anything on a surface, like walls and tables.

Correct: Lots of people wait at the bus stop. Incorrect: Lots of people wait in the bus stop.
We use at to talk about exact locations, like at the bus stop, or at home.
title: At (Place)
Capitalization: Names
description:
Correct: Sarah's birthday is coming soon. Incorrect: sarah's birthday is coming soon.
We capitalize names of people (Sarah, Abraham Lincoln).

Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).
title: Writing the Date

description:
Correct: He broke my favorite cup. Incorrect: He breaked my favorite cup.
The past tense of ""break"" is broke.
title: Broke

description: With Still: I don't like roller coasters. Still, I think theme parks are fun. Without Still: I don't like roller coasters. I think theme parks are fun. We use still at the beginning of a sentence to say something is true despite what was said earlier. We place a comma after still (Still, I think theme parks are fun).
title: Still
Meanwhile
description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).

title: Sheep
description:
Singular: Do you own a sheep? Plural: Do you own three sheep?
The word ""sheep"" does not change when it becomes plural.

title: I'm
description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for ""I am"" is made by writing I'm.

Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.
title: These & Those

description:
Correct: Do you know how many potatoes can fit in this sack? Incorrect: Do you know how many potatos can fit in this sack?
Nouns that end in ""o"" (potato) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we add an ""es"" to the end of the word (potatoes).
title: Ends with ""o""
Foot vs. Feet
description:
Correct: Can you juggle the ball with both feet? Incorrect: Can you juggle the ball with both foots?
The word ""foot"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (foot) into a double ""e"" (feet).

Correct: Where are the children playing right now? Incorrect: Where are the childs playing right now?
The word ""child"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we add ""ren"" to the end (children).
title: Child vs. Children

description:
Correct: Did you know great white sharks lose hundreds of teeth every year? Incorrect: Did you know great white sharks lose hundreds of tooths every year?
The word ""tooth"" has an irregular plural form, similar to the word ""foot"". To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (tooth) into a double ""e"" (teeth).
title: Tooth vs. Teeth

description:
Correct: I think there are some mice living in the walls. Incorrect: I think there are some mouses living in the walls.
The word ""mouse"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""ouse"" (mouse) to ""ice"" (mice).
title: Mouse vs. Mice
Person vs. People
description:
Correct: I think we can fit at east three people in each room. Incorrect: I think we can fit at least three persons in each room.
The word ""person"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""rson"" (person) to ""ople"" (people).

title: Deer
description:
Singular: I saw a deer crossing the road earlier. Plural: I saw ten deer crossing the road earlier.
The word ""deer"" does not change when it becomes plural.

Reflexive: Steven sees himself becoming team captain one day. Non-Reflexive: I see Steven becoming team captain one day.
If a male subject (Steven) does something to himself, we use a reflexive pronoun (himself). In the second example, the subject (I) is seeing someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
title: Himself

description:
Reflexive: Jasmine heard herself singing through the speakers. Non-Reflexive: He heard Jasmine singing through the speakers.
If a female subject (Jasmine) does something to herself, we use a reflexive pronoun (herself). In the second example, the subject (He) is listening to someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
title: Herself
Itself
description:
Reflexive: My computer can shut itself off. Non-Reflexive: I can shut down my computer.
If an object (computer) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (itself). In the second example, the subject of the sentence (I) is shutting the computer down, and not shutting himself down, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

title: Ourselves
description:
Reflexive: We worked ourselves to the point of exhaustion. Non-Reflexive: Our company works almost 80 hours a week.
If the subject (We) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (ourselves). In the second example, the company is making us work instead of us working ourselves, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

title: Yourselves
description:
Reflexive: I see that you all really applied yourselves for this assignment. Non-Reflexive: I see that you worked really hard for this assignment.
When we address multiple people (you all) doing something to themselves, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourselves).

title: Themselves
description:
Reflexive: The models showed themselves off in various outfits. Non-Reflexive: The camera crew showed the models the pictures they took.
If the subject (models) does something to themselves, we use a reflexive pronoun (themselves). Sentences where the subject (crew) does not do something to itself do not need a reflexive pronoun.

Correct: After three years of practice, I became a skillful archer. Incorrect: After three years of practice, I becomed a skillful archer.
The past tense of ""become"" is became.
title: Became

description:
Correct: My mom built that chicken coop last year. Incorrect: My mom builded that chicken coop last year.
The past tense of ""build"" is built.
title: Built

description:
Correct: I'm glad you came to my party. Incorrect: I'm glad you comed to my party.
The past tense of ""come"" is came.
title: Came
Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles
description: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.

With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".
title: Regular Past Participles
Eaten
description: Correct: I have eaten pancakes before. Incorrect: I have eated pancakes before. The past participle for ""eat"" is eaten.

title: Misplaced Modifiers
description: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.

title: Using Quill
description: Correct: A crafty smile flitted across the shrew's rugged face. Incorrect: a crafty smile flitted across the shrew's rugged face We always capitalize the first letter of the first word of a sentence (A). We end our sentences with proper punctuation: a period, a question mark, or an exclamation mark (face.).

The verb throw has an irregular past tense form, threw, and an irregular participle form: thrown.
The noun throne is the ceremonial chair used by a king or some other ruler.
title: Thrown, Throne

description: Correct: The instructions say, ""Turning the screws clockwise makes them tighter."" Incorrect: The instructions say, ""Turning the screws clockwise makes them tighter. We write quotation marks at the beginning and the end of a quotation.
title: Quotations Come in Pairs
Meant, Mint
description:
The verb mean (to communicate, indicate, signify) has an irregular past tense form: meant. From this same root we get the noun meaning.
The noun mint refers to various aromatic plants whose highly flavored leaves are used in cooking (e.g. peppermint, spearmint). The same word also refer to a place where money is coined.

title: Although
description: The word although means ""even though"" or ""in spite of the fact that."" It is a subordinating conjunction. Make sure you spell this as one word: although (not ""all though"").

The word please can be a verb meaning ""to satisfy, to delight,"" or it can be an interjection that signals a polite request.
A plea (noun) is an urgent request or an emotional appeal. It can also refer to a legal claim, as when an accused person makes a plea of ""guilty"" or ""not guilty"" in court. The plural form of the noun is pleas.
title: Please, Pleas
Pour, Poor
description: Pour is a verb. It can take an object (She poured some juice into the glass), or it can be intransitive (Water poured from the roof, making a big puddle on the ground). Poor is an adjective that can refer to someone or something that lacks money, or it can refer to someone or something that is unfortunate or deficient in some other way.

title: Loose, Lose
description:
Lose: lose my keys, lose a game, lose one's balance. Loose: the screws were loose, it broke loose.
We use lose when we can't find something, don't have something, or didn't win.
We use loose when something isn't tight, or something is freed.

title: That
description:
Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.

title: Finally, Finely
description:
The adverb finally means in the end, at last. Compare the adjective: final.
The adverb finely can mean ""in tiny pieces"" or it can mean ""elegantly, nicely."" Compare the adjective: fine.

title: Greece, Grease
description:
Greece is the name of a country. The people who live in Greece are called Greeks, and they speak the Greek language. Since Greece is the name of a country, it is always capitalized.
Grease (noun) is an oily or fatty substance. To grease (verb) means to smear something with grease. If something is covered with grease, it is greasy (adjective). The phrase ""greasy spoon"" refers to a restaurant where there is a lot of fried food on the menu.

The word clean can be a verb (I clean, you clean, she cleans), and it can also be an adjective (my clothes are clean). You can make the word into a noun by adding -er: a ""cleaner"" is someone or something who cleans.
The word cleanse is a verb that means to make something completely clean. It can also mean to wash away a stain or impurity. The word is pronounced: /klens/ (rhymes with the word ""lens""). You can also turn this verb into a noun by adding -(e)r: a ""cleanser"" is someone or something that cleanses.
title: Clean, Cleanse

description:
""Don't forget to breathe during the sprints, it will make you run faster."" It was so cold in my room last night I could see my breath.
breath is the verb ""to breath"" as in to inhale. breathe is the air that you exhale, your breathe.
title: Vocabulary: Breath vs Breathe

description:
The verb bear means to carry, and bear can also be the name of an animal, e.g. polar bear, koala bear, panda bear, etc.
The adjective bare means that something is not clothed or covered; it can also refer to something that is empty. The word bare can also be a verb, meaning to uncover something or to expose something to view.
title: Bear, Bare
Then, Than
description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""

Your: I need to borrow your umbrella. You're: I hope that you're going to lend me one.
We use your when something belongs to ""you."" You're means ""you are.""
title: Your, You're

description:
It's: It's a nice day. Its: The dog wags its tail.
It's is the same as ""it is"".
Its means the object (tail) belongs to the subject (dog).
title: It's, Its

description:
There: There is a park by the lake. They're: They're going to the park. Their: They left their Frisbee at the park.
There is used for locations. They're is the same as ""they are"". Their is used when something (they) owns something else (frisbee).
title: There, Their, They're
To, Too & Two
description:
To: I sent an email to you. Too: Brett sent you an email too. Two: Pat sent you not one, but two emails.
To is used mostly to show where something is moving.
Too can either mean ""also"" or ""excessive"". Two is the number after ""one"".

Correct: Mike learned how to read, write, and speak French. Correct: Mike learned how to read, to write, and to speak French. Incorrect: Mike learned how to read, write, and speaking French. If a list of actions begins with words like ""to read"", we do not write ""ing"" at the end of any action in the list.
title: Verbs Beginning with ""to""
Vocabulary: Raised vs Razed
description: My family raised a litter of cats and then put them up for adoption. The demolition crew razed the old office building to the ground. Raised is the past tense form of the verb ""to raise"" which can mean either lifting something up (raise the bar) or to rear a living thing (raise a litter of cats). Razed is the past tense form of the verb ""to raze"" which means to level a building to the ground by completely destroying or burning the structure.

""Don't go in the sauna, its for grownups,"" said the mother to her daughter. ""When you are more grown-up you will learn to like broccoli.
Grownup is a noun which means an adult person. Grown-up when written with a hyphen, is an adjective that means adult-like, or no longer childish.
title: Vocabulary: Grownup vs Grown-up
Vocabulary: Shown vs Shone
description:
I was shown around the mansion by the butler. Pure white light shone down brilliantly around us.
Shown is the past participle of the verb ""to show"". Shone the past participle of the verb ""to shine"".

The sign said, ""You cannot pass here.""
When we write out ""can not"" we either can use the contraction form ""can't"" or we write cannot.
Can not is just a misspelled version of ""cannot,"" and is always incorrect.
title: Vocabulary: Cannot

description: The time to kick a field goal had already passed. ""Don't worry about the fight we had, its all in the past,"" I said to my brother. Passed is the past tense form of the verb to pass. Past has several meanings, but usually refers to an event that took place prior to the present.
title: Vocabulary: Passed vs Past

description:
The happy young couple lived happily ever after, or so they thought...
is always written with a space between the two words. ""Everafter"" is just a misspelling of ever after.
title: Vocabulary: Ever after
Vocabulary: A While vs Awhile
description:
Its been a while since I last saw you. Go study awhile.
A while is a noun that stands for a period of time. Awhile is an adverb that also means ""a period of time""
To make the distinction a little clearer, notice how in the first sentence a while could be replaced with another unit of time, such as two months, and the sentence would still make sense.
Its been a while since I last saw you. Its been two months since I last saw you.
In the second sentence sentence, awhile could be replaced with another adjective, such as quietly, and still make sense.
Go study awhile. Go study quietly.

Correct: The saddles on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Incorrect: The saddle's on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Plural words that do not own something are written without an apostrophe. Words with an apostrophe placed before an ""s"" are singular possessive words.
title: Plural vs. Singular Possessive
Vocabulary: Mary vs Marry
description: ""I refuse to marry!"" said the woman to her father. ""I saw Mary the other day at the supermarket."" Marry is a verb which means ""to wed"". Mary is a name, and therefore is a proper noun. As a result, Mary is always capitalized.

I work on my flip turns every day at swim practice. Pop quizzes are an everyday occurrence in this class. Every day when written with a space, means literally every day. When written without a space, everyday becomes an adjective that means common place or frequently occurring.
title: Vocabulary: Every Day vs Everyday
Vocabulary: Quiet vs Quite
description:
During study hours, the library was so quiet you could hear people turning the pages of their books. It was quite a shock when Marty managed to make it home for Christmas.
Quiet is an adjective that means soft or silent. Quite is an adjective that means ""to a noticeable degree or extent.""

Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).
title: Whose

description: Correct: All the kids splashing around in the pool laughed without a care in the world. Incorrect: All the kids' splashing around in the pool laughed without a care in the world. Plural words that do not own something are written without an apostrophe. Words with an apostrophe at the end are plural possessive words, and own something.
title: Plural vs. Plural Possessive

description: Correct: Let's play a board game together. Incorrect: Lets play a board game together. Let's means ""let us"" and is used for suggestions. Lets without an apostrophe means ""to allow.""
title: Let's
Let's vs Lets
description:
Let's go do some squats at the gym. My brother lets me use his computer sometimes.
Let's, when spelled with an apostrophe, is the contraction form of ""let us"". Lets, when spelled without an apostrophe, means ""allows"" or ""permits"".

title: Dug
description:
Incorrect: The fox quickly digged a hole in the snow to keep warm. Correct: The fox quickly dug a hole in the snow to keep warm.
The past tense of ""dig"" is dug.
Correct: In his excitement, the athlete shouted, ""I won!"" Incorrect: In his excitement, the athlete shouted, ""i won!"" The first letter of the first word in a quotation is always capitalized.
title: Capitalize the First Word of a Quotation.
Using Commas with Numbers
description:
Correct: 1,500,000 Incorrect: 1, 500, 000
We do not put a space before or after a comma when we are writing numbers.

title: Direct vs. Indirect Speech
description: Correct: The sign by the school tells us that we need to drive slowly. Incorrect: The sign by the school tells us that ""we need to drive slowly."" Quotation marks go around direct speech. This means that we place quotation marks around what somebody says, or what a text says. We do not quote what something has told us or tells us (tells us that we need to drive slowly).

title: Multiple Sentences in a Quotation
description: Correct: ""I heard that walnuts are good for removing scratches on furniture. It could be an old wive's tale, however."" Incorrect: I heard that walnuts are good for removing scratches on furniture."" ""It could be an old wive's tale, however."" Not every sentence in a quotation needs quotation marks. Whenever something is said or stated, we write quotation marks at the very beginning and very end.

Correct: After the meal was finished, I asked, ""May I be excused?"" Incorrect: After the meal was finished, I asked ""May I be excused?"" When we write quotations after a speaking verb, we place a comma at the end of the speaking verb (asked,).
title: Commas before Quotations
Commas At the End of Quotations
description: Correct: ""There is something stuck in your teeth,"" said the little boy. Incorrect: ""There is something stuck in your teeth."" said the little boy. When we write a quotation before a speaking verb, we place a comma at the end of the quotation just before the quotation mark. This comma replaces periods.

title: Verbs Ending in ""ing""
description: Correct: Marcus enjoys hiking, climbing, and canoeing. Incorrect: Marcus enjoys hiking, to climb, and canoes all the time. When writing a list of actions, the flow and rhythm of the sentence is improved if all the items in the list (hiking, climbing, and canoeing) are formed the same way. If one action in a list ends with ""ing,"" the others should as well.

Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
title: Possessive Nouns
At (Time)
description:
Correct: I will meet my friend at noon. Incorrect: I will meet my friend on noon.
We use the preposition at for specific times, like 1:30 PM or 7:00 AM.

title: Ends with ""f""
description:
Correct: Two halves always make a whole. Incorrect: Two halfs always make a whole.
Nouns that end in ""f"" (half) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""f"" (half) to ""ves"" (halves).

Correct: Everyone sat quietly while they waited to board the plane. Incorrect: Everyone sitted quietly while they waited to board the plane.
The past tense of ""sit"" is sat.
title: Sat
Went
description:
Correct: My friends and I went shopping an hour ago. Incorrect: My friends and I goed shopping an hour ago.
The past tense of ""go"" is went.

Simple Future: Alice will watch TV when her mother comes home. Future Progressive: Alice will be watching TV when her mother comes home.
Future progressive tense describes an ongoing action (watching tv) that will take place in the future (when her mother comes home). This tense is made by putting words like “will be” or “shall be” in front of the verb, and adding “ing” to the end of the verb (will be watching).
title: Future Progressive

description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.
title: Subjective Pronouns
Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns
description:
Intensive: I organized the meeting myself. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). It did not do something to itself (organized myself).

Of: a bunch of bananas, member of a team, son of a friend, north of Chicago. Off: turn off the lights, my shoes are off, break off some bread.
We use the word of to show how one thing is connected to another thing. We use off to say that something is no longer connected to something else.
title: Off vs. Of
Saw
description:
Correct: We saw a wild boar the other day in the woods. Incorrect: We seen a wild boar the other day in the woods.
The past tense of ""see"" is saw.

Correct: In 1492, Columbus crossed the ocean blue. IncorrectIn 1492 Columbus crossed the ocean blue. When a sentence begins with a prepositional phrase (on the docks, at the park, in 1522), we always put a comma the introductory prepositional phrase.
title: Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases
Practice: Than vs. Then
description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""

title: Verb Tense
description: Correct: I laughed, I cried, and I shouted during the performance. Incorrect: I laughed, I was crying, and I shout during the performance. Sentences flow easily when all the actions in a list have the same ending. This means that each and every action in a list stays in the past, present, or future tense.

title: Verbs Ending in ""ing""
description: Correct: Marcus enjoys hiking, climbing, and canoeing. Incorrect: Marcus enjoys hiking, to climb, and canoes all the time. When writing a list of actions, the flow and rhythm of the sentence is improved if all the items in the list (hiking, climbing, and canoeing) are formed the same way. If one action in a list ends with ""ing,"" the others should as well.

Correct: Mike learned how to read, write, and speak French. Correct: Mike learned how to read, to write, and to speak French. Incorrect: Mike learned how to read, write, and speaking French. If a list of actions begins with words like ""to read"", we do not write ""ing"" at the end of any action in the list.
title: Verbs Beginning with ""to""

uid: Recognizing Innapropriate Shifts in Pronoun Number or Gender-1
title: Pronoun Shift: Singular
description:
Correct: A doctor has an important job because she saves lives. Correct: A doctor has an important job because he saves lives. Incorrect: A doctor has an important job because they save lives.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is singular (doctor), then any pronouns referring to it will will usually be singular as well (he, she).

title: Practice: Parallel Structure
description: Correct: I laughed, I cried, and I shouted during the performance. Incorrect: I laughed, I was crying, and I shout during the performance. Sentences flow easily when all the actions in a list have the same ending. This means that each and every action in a list stays in the past, present, or future tense.

Correct: If they stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them. Incorrect: If you stay in touch, most people will have a lot of options available to them.
Pronouns need to stay the same in gender (she, he) and number (they, them). This means that if the subject is plural (they), then any pronouns referring to it will usually be plural as well (them).
title: Practice: Pronoun Shift
uid: Recognizing Innapropriate Shifts in Pronoun Number or Gender-2

title: Either ... Or
description:
Exactly two options: You can have either soup or salad._
Two or more options: You can have soup or salad.
Whenever either is placed before or, we are presented with exactly two options (soup or salad). If the two options share a verb, either is written after the verb (have either soup or salad). If the two options have different verbs, either is written before the first verb (You can either run or lift weights).
If there are two or more options, we do not use either, but still use or.

title: Neither ... Nor
description: Neither, nor: My friend is neither snowboarding nor skiing today. Either, or: My friend is either snowboarding or skiing today. Neither and nor are used the same way as the words ""either"" and ""or"". However, neither and nor are used for negative sentences.

title: Why

description: With Both: Both Tom and Michelle like swimming. Without Both: Tom likes swimming. Michelle also likes swimming. Both can be used with and to describe two things at the same time (Both Tom and Michelle). We place both before the first thing, then use and for the second thing.

description:
Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.

Not only is usually placed before one idea, while but also is used instead of the word ""and"".

description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. Present Progressive
description:
Simple Present: Jesse thinks about seagulls. Present Progressive: Jesse is thinking about seagulls right now.
Present progressive tense describes an ongoing action that is happening right now (Jesse is thinking right now). This tense is made by putting words like ""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" to the end of the verb (is thinking).

Correct: Let's go to the living room, where we will serve drinks. Incorrect: Let's go to the living room, when we will serve drinks.
Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).
title: Practice: Where, Why, When
Past Progressive
description:
Simple Past: James cleaned the mess he made when his mom walked in the room. Past Progressive: James was cleaning the mess he made when his mom walked in the room.
Past progressive tense describes something which was happening (was cleaning) when something else occurred (mom walked in). This tense is made by putting words like""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" at the end of the verb (was cleaning).

Simple Future: Alice will watch TV when her mother comes home. Future Progressive: Alice will be watching TV when her mother comes home.
Future progressive tense describes an ongoing action (watching tv) that will take place in the future (when her mother comes home). This tense is made by putting words like ""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" to the end of the verb (will be watching).
title: Future Progressive

description: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).

Yourself
description:
Reflexive: Why don't you lift yourself out of the hole? Non-Reflexive: Why don't you lift Alex out of the hole?
If a subject (you) does something to its itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourself). Sentences where the subject (you) does not do something to itself (Alex) do not use a reflexive pronoun.

Reflexive: I see that you all really applied yourselves for this assignment. Non-Reflexive: I see that you worked really hard for this assignment.
When we address multiple people (you all) doing something to themselves, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourselves).

Reflexive: Jasmine heard herself singing through the speakers. Non-Reflexive: He heard Jasmine singing through the speakers.

Is: John is behind the curtain. Are: The men are next to the bar. Am: I am under a bridge.
A nominal prepositional phrase is used to say where something is. Nominal prepositional phrases (behind the curtain, next to the bar, under a bridge) are placed after the verb to be (is, are, am).
title: At (Time)

description:
Correct: I will meet my cousin in the fall. Incorrect: I will meet my cousin at the fall.
We use in for months, seasons, and times of day, like October, winter or morning.
title: In (Time)
On (Time)
description:
Correct: I will meet with my counselor on Monday. Incorrect: I will meet with my counselor in Monday.
We use on for days of the week and certain dates, like Monday or October 30th.

Correct: Lots of people wait at the bus stop. Incorrect: Lots of people wait in the bus stop.
We use at to talk about exact locations, like at the bus stop, or at home.
title: At (Place)
In (Place)
description:
Correct: I had a great time in London. Incorrect: I had a great time at London.
We use in when we are inside or within a place, like in France, or in a car.

title: On (Place)
description:
Correct: My grandparents keep a picture of me on their mantle. Incorrect: My grandparents keep a picture of me at their mantle.
We use on for anything on a surface, like walls and tables.

Correct: I will meet my friend at noon. Incorrect: I will meet my friend on noon.
We use the preposition at for specific times, like 1:30 PM or 7:00 AM.
title: Practice: At, In, On (Time)

description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.

The
description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).

Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).

title: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-1
description:
Active Voice: The student use Quill.
Passive Voice: Quill is used by the students.
A verb's voice tells whether a subject receives or performs an action. If the subject receives the action, it is passive, and if the subject performs the action, it is active.
The passive voice is usually written with a form of ""to be"" and then the past participle of a verb.
uid: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-1

description:
Active Voice: The student use Quill.
Passive Voice: Quill is used by the students.
A verb's voice tells whether a subject receives or performs an action. If the subject receives the action, it is passive, and if the subject performs the action, it is active.
The passive voice is usually written with a form of ""to be"" and then the past participle of a verb.
title: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-2
uid: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-2

description:
Active Voice: Tom (subject) shipped (verb) the package.
Passive Voice: The passage (subject) was shipped (verb) by Tom.
To change a sentence from the active voice to the passive voice, you must change the subject so that instead of doing the verb, the verb is being done to it.
title: Change Sentences from Active to Passive-1
uid: Change Sentences from Active to Passive-1
Change Sentences from Passive to Active-1
description:
Passive Voice: The sausage (subject) was eaten (verb) by Ryan.
Active Voice: Ryan (subject) ate (verb) the sausage.
To change a sentence from the passive voice to the active voice, you must change the subject so that instead of the verb being done to it, the subject does the verb.
title: Change Sentences from Passive to Active-1

Correct: Some people say cats have nine lives. Incorrect: Some people say cats have nine lifes.
Nouns that end in ""fe"" (life) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""fe"" (life) to ""ves"" (lives).
title: Ends with ""fe""

description:
Correct: Two halves always make a whole. Incorrect: Two halfs always make a whole.
Nouns that end in ""f"" (half) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""f"" (half) to ""ves"" (halves).
title: Ends with ""f""
Ends with ""o""
description:
Correct: Do you know how many potatoes can fit in this sack? Incorrect: Do you know how many potatos can fit in this sack?
Nouns that end in ""o"" (potato) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we add an ""es"" to the end of the word (potatoes).

Correct: Are you mice, or are you men? Incorrect: Are you mice, or are you mans?
The word ""man"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (man) to an ""e"" (men).

description:
Correct: Can you juggle the ball with both feet? Incorrect: Can you juggle the ball with both foots?
The word ""foot"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (foot) into a double ""e"" (feet).

Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.
title: Common Nouns

description:
Examples: John, Sarah, London, Japan, and Yankees
Proper nouns are names for people, places, and things, such as John, or Japan. All proper nouns are capitalized.
title: Proper Nouns
Possessive Nouns
description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

Correct: The red team scored the winning goal in the game. Incorrect: The red panel scored the winning goal in the game.
Collective nouns are words like team, panel, bunch, pack, etc. They usually are singular and describe a group of things (group of people).
Team is a collective noun generally used to describe a group working towards a common cause, or in competition with another group. For example, a sports team, oxen team, or
title: Use Collective Nouns-1
Practice: Contractions
description:
Separate: I do not go to school on Saturday. Contraction: I don't go to school on Saturday.
To make ""do"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write don't.

title: Use Collective Nouns-2
description:
Correct: Thepanel of jurors found him innocent. Incorrect: Thebunch of jurors found him innocent.
Panel is a collective noun generally used to describe a group of figures with authority that are discussing something. For example, judges, juries, advisors, aids, etc...

title: Practice: Possessive Nouns
description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.
title: Practice: Singular And Plural Nouns
uid: Singular and Plural Nouns with Matching Verbs-alpha

title: Practice: Common and Proper Nouns
description:
Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.

title: Use Collective Nouns-3
description:
Correct: There are 12 diapers in a pack. Incorrect: There are 12 diapers in a pack.
Pack is a collective noun that can have many different meanings. It can be a group of things packaged together, for example, soda, gum, or candy. It can also refer to groups of animals that live together, especially wolves.

title: Use Collective Nouns-4
description:
Correct: There is a huge group of people at the front gate. Incorrect: There is a huge bunch of people at the front gate.
Group is a collective noun that usually refers to a number of people or objects that are nearby or considered together as one unit. For example, a group of students, a group of packages, a group of fruits, etc...

Past: I walked to school. Present: I walk to school.
When we want to talk about things that happened earlier, we usually add ""ed"" to the end of regular verbs to make them past tense.
title: Past Tense
Practice: Future Tense
description:
Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).

title: Future Tense
description:
Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).

title: Practice: And, Or
description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.

Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.
title: And

description:
Adjective: The park we visited was really beautiful. Adverb: You performed beautifully yesterday.
Adjectives (beautiful) are used to describe nouns (park).
title: Practice: Adjectives and Adverbs

description:
Not Connected: Would you like spaghetti? Would you like a hamburger? Connected: Would you like spaghetti, or would you like a hamburger?
Or connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, or is used to show a choice between spaghetti or a hamburger.
title: Or

description:
Not Connected: I don't like hamburgers. I will have spaghetti. Connected: I don't like hamburgers, so I will have spaghetti.
So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.
title: So
Practice: Past Tense Verbs
description:

Not Connected: I like this spaghetti. There is a lot of cheese in it. Connected: I like this spaghetti because there is a lot of cheese in it.
Because connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, because is used to show that the amount of cheese is the reason the spaghetti is liked.
title: Because

description:

So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.

Adjective: My car is really slow. Adverb: I drive slowly when it is raining.
Adverbs are used to describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They usually describe how an action is being done (drive slowly).
title: Adverbs

description:
Adjective: Careful, that knife is sharp. Adverb: I sharply turned the car around.
If an adjective ends in a consonant (sharp), then we usually add ""ly"" onto the end of the adjective to make it an adverb (sharply).

Adjectives ending in ""y"" (happy), become adverbs by changing the ""y"" to an ""i"", and then adding ""ly""(happily).

description:

To make a contraction with ""I"" and ""have"", we write I've.

Adjective: You are brave enough to face your fears. Adverb: Rita bravely faced her fears.
Adjectives ending in ""e"" (brave), become adverbs by simply adding ""ly"" to the end of the word (bravely).
