Practice: Eaten, Been, Regular Past Participles
description: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".

title: Lost
description: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.

title: Practice: However, Still
description: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but"". We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).
Correct: We have made many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. Incorrect: We have maked many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. The past participle for ""make"" is made.
title: Made

description: Correct: Velma has gone to visit her brother in the hospital. Incorrect: Velma has goed to visit her brother in the hospital. The past participle of ""go"" is gone.
title: Gone

description: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".
title: Regular Past Participles
Practice: Use Commas for Dates and Lists
description:
Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).
uid: Use Commas for Dates and Lists.-alpha

title: Use Commas in Addresses
description: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.

title: Eaten
description: Correct: I have eaten pancakes before. Incorrect: I have eated pancakes before. The past participle for ""eat"" is eaten.

title: Been
description: Correct: I have been in a band before. Incorrect: I have beed in a band before. The past participle for ""be"" is been.

title: Practice: Use Commas in Addresses
description: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.

title: Still
description: With Still: I don't like roller coasters. Still, I think theme parks are fun. Without Still: I don't like roller coasters. I think theme parks are fun. We use still at the beginning of a sentence to say something is true despite what was said earlier. We place a comma after still (Still, I think theme parks are fun).

title: Meanwhile
description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).
Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.
title: Practice: Made, Lost, Gone
Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases
description: Correct: In 1492, Columbus crossed the ocean blue. IncorrectIn 1492 Columbus crossed the ocean blue. When a sentence begins with a prepositional phrase (on the docks, at the park, in 1522), we always put a comma the introductory prepositional phrase.

title: Using Periods
description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.

Correct: Victor, Lucas, and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor,Lucas,and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor ,Lucas ,and Don play basketball.
We put a space after a comma. We do not put a space before a comma.
title: Using Commas
Using Periods with Numbers
description:
Correct: They hiked 1.7 miles. Incorrect: They hiked 1. 7 miles.
We do not put a space before or after a period when we are writing numbers.

title: Using Quotation Marks
description: Correct: Our librarian always reminds us, ""Speak softly in the library."" Incorrect: Our librarian always reminds us, "" Speak softly in the library."" Whenever we use quotation marks, they always go right next to a word or punctuation (""Speak softly in the library.""). We never put in extra spaces between quotation marks and the words next to them.

title: Practice: Spaces with Punctuation
description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.

With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but."" We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).
title: However

description: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.""
title: Misplaced Modifiers
Practice: Subjective, Objective, and Possessive Pronouns
description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.

title: Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns
description:
Intensive: I myself organized the meeting. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the word emphasizes the the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). When the word is used as a reflexive pronoun, it emphasizes what the subject does to itself (organized myself).

Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.
title: Practice: Misplaced Modifiers
Subjective Pronouns
description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.

title: Object Pronouns
description:
Correct: Will you please call her when you finish the poster? Incorrect: Will you please call she when you finish the poster? Also Incorrect: Will you please call hers when you finish the poster?
Object pronouns (her) are words like ""me"", ""you"", ""him"", ""her"", ""it"", ""us"", and ""them"". Object pronouns go after the verb (call).

title: Possessive Pronouns
description:
Correct: Our project is more difficult than theirs. Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than they. Also Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than them.
Possessive pronouns (theirs) are words like ""mine"", ""yours"", ""his"", ""hers"", ""its"", ""ours"", and ""theirs"". They refer to something the subject owns (project).

title: Tag Questions
description: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to confirm what we just asked, or suggest an answer. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we). If the first part is negative, then the tag question is positive.
uid: Use a Comma to Set off the Words ""Yes"" and ""No""-1

description: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to agree, disagree, or confirm what someone just said. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we).
title: Practice: Commas for ""Yes"" and ""No,"" Tag Questions, and Addressing People
uid: Use a Comma to Set off the Words ""Yes"" and ""No""-alpha

title: Practice: Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns
description:
Intensive: I organized the meeting myself. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). It did not do something to itself (organized myself).

Correct: Yes, my husband is a lawyer. Incorrect: Yes my husband is a lawyer. Correct: No, I don't want to go. Incorrect: No I don't want to go. When we begin a sentence with yes or no, we always put a comma afterwards.
title: Yes & No
uid: Use a Comma to Set off the Words ""Yes"" and ""No""-2
Recognize and Correct Innapropriate Shifts in Verb Voice and Mood-2
title: Verb Mood Shift
description: Correct: If I were you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. Incorrect: If I was you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. When we wish for something, or wonder if something could happen, we use ""were"" instead of ""was"". If it is something that could or has been true, we use ""was"" instead of were.

Correct: Can we go, Paul? Incorrect: Can we go Paul? Correct: Sarah, you should go to practice. Incorrect: Sarah you should go to practice. If we address somebody at the end of a sentence, we place a comma before their name. If we address somebody at the beginning of a sentence we place a comma after their name.
title: Addressing People
uid: Use a Comma to Set off the Words ""Yes"" and ""No""-3
Use Colons and Commas in a List-1
description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.
title: Commas in a List

uid: Use Colons and Commas in a List-2
description: Correct: The box was filled with stuff: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. Incorrect: The box has: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. We use colons (filled with stuff:) to begin a list. Colons can only be used after complete sentences. Colons are never placed after main verb of the sentence they are added too. After the colon begins the list, we place commas after each item in the list.
title: Colons
First Word of a Sentence
description:
Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.

title: Proper Nouns
description:
Correct: Do you have a class with Mr. Thompson? Incorrect: Do you have a class with mr. thompson?
We always capitalize the first letter of proper nouns (Mr. Thompson), which are people, places, and things, with names. We also capitalize any titles that might come before the proper noun, such as Mr., Ms., Dr., President, Professor, ect. Don't forget, ""I"" is a proper noun and is always capitalized.

title: Practice: Correct Capitalization
description:
Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.

title: Practice: Colons and Commas in a List
description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.
uid: Use Colons and Commas in a List-alpha

title: Quotations
description:
Correct: We heard a booming voice shout, ""Who are you?"" Incorrect: We heard a booming voice shout, ""who are you?""
When we use quotations in a sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (Who) of the quote as though it was starting a new sentence.

Correct: I live on 15 Deepwood Rd in Hartford CT. Incorrect: I live on 15 deepwood rd in hartford ct.
The names of roads, towns, and states in addresses are all proper nouns, so they are capitalized. Don't forget to capitalize all the proper nouns in your address whenever you write it down.
title: Addresses
Singular Possessive
description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

title: Practice: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names
description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).
uid: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names-alpha

title: Plural vs. Singular Possessive
description: Correct: The saddles on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Incorrect: The saddle's on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Plural words that do not own something are written without an apostrophe. Words with an apostrophe placed before an ""s"" are singular possessive words.

Many Boys: Do not touch the boys' gear. One Boy: Do not touch the boy's gear. When multiple people or things own something we place an apostrophe after the ""s"" (boys'). When just one person or thing owns something we put the apostrophe before the ""s"".
title: Plural Possessive

description: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).
title: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue
uid: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue-1

title: Holidays
description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).
uid: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names-1
Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names-2
description:
Correct: My favorite baseball team is the Yankees. Incorrect: My favorite baseball team is the yankees.
We capitalize all product names. Product names include companies (Microsoft), sports teams (Yankees), and brand names (Coca-Cola).
title: Product Names

uid: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names-3
description:
Correct: I am moving to Los Angeles next month. Incorrect: I am moving to los angeles next month.
We capitalize the names of all geographic places (cities, countries, towns, mountains, etc).
title: Geographic Names

uid: Use Commas for Dates and Lists.-1
title: Writing the Date
description:
Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).

uid: Use Commas for Dates and Lists.-2
title: Writing Lists
description:
Incorrect: I'll have milk and toast and a muffin. Correct: I'll have milk, toast, and a muffin.
When we write lists of three or more, we put a comma after each item in the list. We also put the word ""and"" before the last item of the list.

title: Practice: Possessive Nouns
description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.

uid: Capitalize Dates and Names of People-1
description:
Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).
title: Capitalization: Dates

uid: Capitalize Dates and Names of People-2
title: Capitalization: Names
description:
Correct: Sarah's birthday is coming soon. Incorrect: sarah's birthday is coming soon.
We capitalize names of people (Sarah, Abraham Lincoln).

Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).
title: Practice: Capitalizing Dates and Names of People
uid: Capitalize Dates and Names of People-alpha

title: A
description:
Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).

Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).
title: A
Than vs. Then
description:
Than: I am older than my brother. Then: The sky was pink, and then it became dark.
We use than to compare two or more things. We use then to say ""at that time.""

Correct: Where are the children playing right now? Incorrect: Where are the childs playing right now?
The word ""child"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we add ""ren"" to the end (children).
title: Practice: Children, People

description:
Reflexive: We worked ourselves to the point of exhaustion. Non-Reflexive: Our company works almost 80 hours a week.
If the subject (We) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (ourselves). In the second example, the company is making us work instead of us working ourselves, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
title: Ourselves

description: Correct: That hat doesn't fit me because it is too small. Incorrect: That had didn't fit me because it is too small. Everything that happens in the present must be written in the present tense (doesn't fit me because it is too small). For things that happen in the past, everything must be written in the past tense. Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.
title: Verb Tense Shift
uid: Recognize and Correct Innapropriate Shifts in Verb Voice and Mood-1

title: An
description:
Incorrect: I saw a owl last night. Correct: I saw an owl last night.
A is used before nouns that start with a consonant sound (everything but a, e, i, o, u). An is used before nouns that start with a vowel sound.

title: Verb Tense Shift

Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.

description:
Correct: Todd has become a great student since he started studying more.
Incorrect: Todd has became a great student since he started studying more.
The past participle of ""go"" is gone.
title: Became
However
description: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but."" We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).

With ""and"": I just had a big and tasty calzone. Without ""and"": I just had a big, tasty calzone. Whenever you have two adjectives (big and tasty) describing something (calzone), you do not have to use ""and"" like you normally do for lists. You can write a comma after the first adjective to describe something (big, tasty calzone).
title: Two Adjectives

Not only … but also: He was not only an excellent athlete, but also a great musician. And: He was an excellent athlete and a great musician. We use not only and but also to connect two different ideas to something. We always place a comma before but also in these kinds of sentences. Not only is usually placed before one idea, while but also is used instead of the word ""and.""
title: Not Only ... But Also

description: Not only, but also: He was not only an excellent athlete, but also a great musician. And: He was an excellent athlete and a great musician.
